lsr_details.sentence: The mountain air bit at the strip of skin between his glove and his sleeve, a petty little nip that reminded Jax he’d vo
The clearing looked right: flat enough if you ignored the stubborn hummock in the corner, a skirt of larch and spruce he
The kids were already talking over each other, a flock of eager noises, and he let them, hands on his pack straps, a gri
It’s a quiet little dragon with one trick.” “Blowing everything up?” Freckles asked, a little hopeful, like he wanted so
Loop, feed through, pull like your life depends on it.” He did it slow.
He dug a hand into the duff and felt the cold bite more serious.
Night would do what it always did in the mountains: come early and come hungry.
The cord straps bit into his shoulders and he welcomed the bite.
The cord straps bit into his shoulders and he welcomed the bite.
The needle pointed where it always did, patient and smug.
He would make a face, pretend to be scandalized, and then feed them, and then they’d sit around a fire and talk about no
The needles under his soles whispered, and the whisper sounded nervous.
“Like that’s going to-” The cord bit into his jacket and then into him.
When he moved his head, it didn’t mirror him, it ate the notion of a mirror.
Needles bit through.
It wanted him.
“Listen,” he said, a joke for no one.
His grip blew apart.
He didn’t scream.
He tried to listen.
This was being peeled, then pulled through a place too tired to support nouns.
He tried to scream.
The scream had no throat.
Feed through.
He made a list of supplies he would need when he got back, which was either optimism or stubborn delusion.
"YEARS of this and when I get out I'm going to be FUCKING INSUFFERABLE." "Assuming I get out," he whispered later, terro
Eventually, again, nonsense word, he noticed that one of the current's strands had a different weight, a mineral taste t

Your body knows how to endure, how to grip, how to move.
The pale stones sat in the grid, patient as change in a collection plate.
"I want to listen well.
The wood grain took a half-step to the left and then to the right, like it couldn’t decide which version of itself it wa
Sound cut and came back with a metallic taste.
It was glossy enough to throw back a smear of the world and yet somehow ate light at the same time.
It was the kind of voice people learned early to obey so they could get on with their lives.
The mayor’s mouth did not forgive him for trying.
The pull was here if he reached for it, not a roar, not the world-eating braid, just a background insistence that a mach
Jax kept his gaze on his own hands and let the door breathe cold, then a shape slid in, all leather and hush, a longer s
The lock was more stubborn suggestion than mechanism: iron loop, pin, bored wood with a habit of splintering.

A low mist clung to a flat that lied about being a meadow until you watched the mud breathe.
He followed her exactly and filed the process: test, listen, trust your weight to the answer you got not the answer you
The stones had a good grip, angled to accept boots without testing your humors.
He licked his lips and tasted resin and his own stubborn grin.
He turned in place slowly, his body hungry for the sight.
The sinew wanted to be obstinate, but Jax was stubborn in the right way.
Her thumbs pressed against his knuckles, small and firm, steadying the moment his grip wanted to get creative and invent
He felt the sinew bite on itself at exactly the tension he would have told a kid to look for; he found himself grinning
They walked the ring once, making small adjustments to ferns that would otherwise bump a trigger, adding a whisper of cr
It felt good to care about little angles that mattered; it was better than caring about big angles that would eat you an
She cupped the air around the nearest spear of growth, showing the path you could thread if you placed your foot on the
Jax had never respected the volume of a scream until it came out of a barrel chest with tusks.
It crashed off, breaking the understory’s rules, and kept going until the trees ate the sound and made it theirs.
“Breathe,” she said in her own language and in his bones.
His sense of balance ticked one notch to the left into “unfair.” Lira watched with that hunger she kept tight on a leash
It settled deeper than the others, back behind everything where his stubborn hung out.
He weighed that with the tired humor of a man who had been handed three impossible things today and was only allowed to
Smoke climbed in angry threads from a dozen roofs.
In the sudden mechanical silence, only the wind's shriek and the ocean's roar remained.
The blade bit into the wood with a thunderous whine, sending golden sawdust cascading to the floor in thick clouds.
Pine logs, still fragrant with sap and forest earth, rolled down the conveyor toward the hungry steel teeth.
By noon, his shoulders ached from wrestling the heavy oak planks, their grain dark and stubborn compared to the yielding
Steam rose from the freshly exposed wood, releasing the sweet smell of cedar and the sharper bite of hemlock.
The planar's roar dominated the afternoon shift, smoothing rough boards into precise lumber.
The smell of fresh sawdust filled his nostrils as the blade bit into the timber, sending curls of wood spiraling to the
Oak logs, still weeping sap from yesterday's cut, rolled down the conveyor toward the hungry teeth of steel.
Steam rose from the fresh lumber as the saw bit through decades of growth rings, transforming towering timber into neat
There was no time for perfectionism here, only the brutal calculus of triage: stop the bleeding, stabilize the patient,
Another patient was already being prepared on the adjacent table.
"Next," he called over the constant rumble of distant guns, never looking up from his patient.
The lucky ones received whiskey and a leather bit.
The war machine demanded its pound of flesh, and he fought to deny it one patient at a time.
When the color dulled too much, he thrust the piece back into the forge's hungry flames.
